questions.question: What is the defining characteristic of unsupervised learning?

options.A: Learning from labeled data.
options.B: Learning through interaction with an environment and receiving rewards.
options.C: Learning patterns and structures from unlabeled data.
options.D: Predicting a continuous output based on input features.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of clustering in unsupervised learning?

options.A: To predict a target variable.
options.B: To group similar data points together into clusters.
options.C: To reduce the number of features in the dataset.
options.D: To discover associations between different items.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common clustering algorithm?

options.A: Linear Regression
options.B: Logistic Regression
options.C: K-Means
options.D: Support Vector Machines

questions.question: What is the role of the 'K' parameter in the K-Means algorithm?

options.A: It represents the learning rate of the algorithm.
options.B: It specifies the number of clusters to be formed.
options.C: It determines the maximum number of iterations.
options.D: It controls the penalty for outliers.

questions.question: What is hierarchical clustering?

options.A: A clustering algorithm that assigns each data point to a predefined hierarchy of clusters.
options.B: A clustering algorithm that builds a hierarchy of clusters, either top-down (divisive) or bottom-up (agglomerative).
options.C: A clustering algorithm that requires the number of clusters to be specified beforehand.
options.D: A clustering algorithm that is only suitable for large datasets.

questions.question: What is DBSCAN (Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise)?

options.A: A centroid-based clustering algorithm.
options.B: A hierarchical clustering algorithm.
options.C: A density-based clustering algorithm that groups together points that are closely packed together, marking as outliers points that lie alone in low-density regions.
options.D: A clustering algorithm that requires specifying the number of clusters.

questions.question: What is dimensionality reduction in unsupervised learning?

options.A: The process of increasing the number of features in a dataset.
options.B: The process of reducing the number of features in a dataset while preserving important information.
options.C: The process of grouping similar data points together.
options.D: The process of predicting a target variable without labels.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common dimensionality reduction technique?

options.A: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)
options.B: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
options.C: Linear Regression
options.D: Decision Trees

questions.question: What is the goal of Principal Component Analysis (PCA)?

options.A: To find the optimal number of clusters in a dataset.
options.B: To transform the data into a new set of orthogonal variables (principal components) that capture the most variance in the data.
options.C: To classify data points into predefined categories.
options.D: To discover association rules between items.

questions.question: What is t-SNE (t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding)?

options.A: A linear dimensionality reduction technique.
options.B: A non-linear dimensionality reduction technique primarily used for visualizing high-dimensional data in lower dimensions (typically 2D or 3D).
options.C: A clustering algorithm based on density.
options.D: A technique for feature selection.

questions.question: What is association rule mining in unsupervised learning?

options.A: A technique for predicting a continuous target variable.
options.B: A technique for grouping similar data points together.
options.C: A technique for discovering interesting relationships or associations between variables in large datasets.
options.D: A technique for reducing the number of dimensions in the data.

questions.question: What are 'support' and 'confidence' in the context of association rule mining?

options.A: Metrics for evaluating the performance of a classification model.
options.B: Measures of the frequency and reliability of association rules.
options.C: Parameters used in clustering algorithms.
options.D: Techniques for dimensionality reduction.

questions.question: What is anomaly detection (or outlier detection) in unsupervised learning?

options.A: The process of finding the central tendency of the data.
options.B: The process of identifying data points that deviate significantly from the majority of the data.
options.C: The process of grouping similar data points.
options.D: The process of reducing the number of features.

questions.question: Which of the following is an unsupervised anomaly detection technique?

options.A: Support Vector Machines (SVM)
options.B: Logistic Regression
options.C: Isolation Forest
options.D: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) for classification

questions.question: How is the performance of unsupervised learning algorithms typically evaluated?

options.A: Using labeled data and accuracy metrics.
options.B: Using intrinsic metrics (e.g., silhouette score for clustering) or extrinsic metrics (if some ground truth is available).
options.C: By directly measuring the prediction error.
options.D: By visualizing the decision boundaries.

questions.question: What is the silhouette score used for?

options.A: Evaluating the performance of a regression model.
options.B: Evaluating the quality of clusters formed by a clustering algorithm.
options.C: Measuring the accuracy of a classification model.
options.D: Assessing the amount of variance explained by principal components.

questions.question: What are autoencoders primarily used for in unsupervised learning?

options.A: Classification tasks.
options.B: Regression tasks.
options.C: Dimensionality reduction and feature learning.
options.D: Time series forecasting.

questions.question: What are generative models in the context of unsupervised learning?

options.A: Models that are used to classify data points.
options.B: Models that learn the underlying probability distribution of the data and can generate new data points similar to the training data.
options.C: Models that are used for dimensionality reduction.
options.D: Models that are used for clustering data points.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a generative model in unsupervised learning?

options.A: K-Means Clustering
options.B: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
options.C: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)
options.D: Support Vector Machines (SVM)

questions.question: In what scenarios is unsupervised learning particularly useful?

options.A: When labeled data is abundant and readily available.
options.B: When the goal is to predict a specific outcome with high accuracy.
options.C: When the data is unlabeled and the goal is to discover hidden structures or patterns.
options.D: When the problem involves sequential decision-making with rewards.
